Dilbar K. started her business by selling apples. Today, she also sells bananas, cherries, etc. She asks for $600 loan to increase the volume of the goods sold during this fruit season.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Кобилова Дилбар, является активным клиентом МЗФ «Микроинвест» более 3 лет. В сфере предпринимательской деятельностью занимается не менее 9 лет. Она замужем и имеет 3 детей. Свою деятельность начала с продажи яблок. Сейчас также торгует бананами, черешней и т.д. Так как сейчас сезон фруктов, ей необходимо 600$ для увеличения товарооборота.

loans.use: To increase the volume of the goods sold

loans.name: Braulio Brígido

texts.es:
Braulio is 37 years old, married and has 2 children. His earnings as an employee was not enough to cover for his family's basic needs; to gain extra money, Braulio and his wife decided to start a business selling groceries. They set up a small area of their house as their store, and little by little, the couple has been increasing their stock. Now, Braulio and his wife already use up a whole room in their house for the store and they hope to keep growing.

At this moment, Braulio needs a $925 loan to buy more merchandise and keep the store well supplied. This way, he will be able to meet his clients' demands. He promises to repay this loan within 4 months. The well-being of this family is in your hands; help them by contributing to the growth of their business. They will be thankful to you.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Braulio tiene 37 años de edad, es casado y padre de dos hijos. Como el salario que recibía de empleado era muy poco, no podía cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia, y para obtener un ingreso extra entre él y su esposa decidieron emprender su negocio con la venta de abarrotes, acondicionaron un pequeño lugar de la casa para realizar sus ventas y poco a poco han estado surtiendo mejor, ahora ya ocupan una habitación completa de su casa para el negocio y esperan continuar creciendo.

En estos momentos Braulio necesita un crédito de $ 925 dólares que empleará para comprar mercancía y surtir mejor su negocio para mantenerse la preferencia de sus clientes, él se compromete a regresar esta cantidad en 4 meses. En tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, ayúdalos contribuyendo el crecimiento de su negocio, ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Primitiva Beatriz

texts.es:
Sra. Primitiva, 43, is from Ancash, a region or "departamento" of Peru. She's a single mother with 4 children. She belongs to the "Senor D. los Milagros D. Chiquian" (Lord of the Miracles of Chiquian) community bank and earns a living making and selling "alfajores" (a traditional cookie in Peru and other parts of South America). She sells her products from her house and at stores in Chiquian; she also sends 400 to 500 alfajores a week to Lima because she has customers there too. She got started making "manjar blanco" (a caramel-like product that is usually an ingredient of alfajores) and she has 10 years experience at this business.

The business requires a lot of work. She preps until midnight and gets up at 5am to bake the alfajores. It's her daily routine.

The loans that she's received from Manuela Ramos have served to grow her business and, in turn, educate her children. Three are professionals. Thanks to the business, too, she's been able to help one of her daughters, a single mother.

With the recently-granted loan of S/.800 (800 Peruvian soles or about US$267), to be repaid over 6 months, she will buy flour, milk and sugar at wholesale prices.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Primitiva, es del Distrito D. Chiquian, Provincia D. Bolognesi -Ancash, tiene 43 años D. edad, es madre soltera y tiene 4 hijos. Pertenece al Banco Comunal "Señor D. los Milagros D. Chiquian", se dedica a la elaboración y venta D. alfajores, venD. en su domicilio, reparte a las tiendas en Chiquian y envía a Lima una vez por semana D. 400 a 500 alfajores porque tiene clientes. Se inició elaborando Manjar Blanco, tiene 10 años trabajando en su negocio.

Este negocio es bastante sacrificado, amasa hasta las 12 a.m. y a las 5 a.m. se levanta para llevar el producto al horno, es su rutina diaria.

Los préstamos recibidos D. Manuela Ramos le han servido para hacer crecer su negocio y ello le ha permitido educar a sus hijos, 3 son profesionales y una D. sus hijas es madre soltera a la que ayuda gracias a su negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos D. S/ 800.00 soles (US$ 267.00 aprox.) pagadero en 6 meses, comprará harina, leche y azúcar al por mayor.

loans.use: Buy ingredients (flour, milk and sugar) for baking business.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience N. is 43 years old, married and has two (2) children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells Weavon, hair cream and cosmetics. She has been in business since 1996. She is in need of US$550 to enable her buy more Weavon and hair cream for sale.

loans.use: To buy more Weavon and hair cream for sale

loans.name: Racheal's Group

texts.en:
Racheal M. wants a loan to buy more second hand clothes in order to meet her customer’s expectations at her shop.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase the stock in her business

loans.name: Cleria Herlinda

texts.es:
Cleria belongs to Banco Comunal Nuevo Horizonte (Nuevo Horizonte Community Bank) located in Unión 589, Calleria district in Ucayali department. She is 55 years old and has a son who's already an adult, but who always takes care of her. She is married and her husband is a chauffeur.

With the first loan of S/. 300 Cleria got from Manuela Ramos, she invested in candies. Currently, Cleria has a food joint and sells candies as well. She gets up at 5:00 a.m. to go to the market and buy groceries to prepare the lunches she sells until 2:00 p.m. Then she takes a break for a couple of hours and starts selling candies until 8:00 p.m.

With the S/. 1,000 loan, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy S/. 200 worth of candies, 1 blender, 1 mixer and will set up a place to sell fresh juice. Cleria is very happy and is independent because she does not have to rely on her husband so much; as a matter of fact, she brings more to the household and is very thankful for the support Manuela Ramos has provided her.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer

La señora Cleria pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuevo Horizonte, ubicado en Jr. Unión 589, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años y es madre de un hijo mayor de edad, pero que siempre está pendiente de ella, es casada y su esposo es chofer. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la venta de golosinas. En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de venta de comidas y golosinas. Se levanta a las 5 a.m. para ir al mercado a comprar sus productos para preparar los almuerzos que vende hasta las 2 p.m., descansa un par de horas y después dedica la a venta de golosinas hasta las 8 p.m. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará S/. 200 en golosinas, 1 licuadora, 1 batidora e implementará un negocio para la venta de jugos. Cleria se siente muy feliz e independiente porque no depende tanto de su esposo, al contrario ella es quien mas aporta en el hogar y da muchas gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Compra de golosinas y activos (licuadora y batidora)

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar has a very small bakery that is located in his house. He bakes the national bread of Tajikistan, called “lepeshka.” His elder brother and mother help him in the business.

Zafar has always been known as a hard-working young man. This year, Zafar is getting married and so he is working even harder to make his business more successful. He will use his income to pay for his wedding party and expand the bakery.

With this loan, Zafar will purchase the flour and coal that he urgently needs to continue baking. He thanks everyone for their support and trust.

loans.use: Purchase coal and flour required for baking

loans.name: Beon

texts.en:
Mrs. Beoun S., 22, is widow with one small child and sells porridge, soups and noodles, earning around $18 per day. She and her child live with her brothers and sisters.

She is requesting a loan to purchase rice to sell in order to gain more profits.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale

loans.name: Gonzalina

texts.en:
Gonzalina A., 40, is the owner of “Despensa Gonza”. Despensas are like mini supermarkets and are very popular in Paraguay. Every despensa is well-known in the neighborhood where it is located. Despensas are often very successful businesses in Paraguay because it is tradition to shop there. The owner knows the customers very well and they usually have a friendly relationship. Generally, the owner will know all of the gossip in the neighborhood and that attracts customers who not only go there to shop but also to hear what is going on in the area. For these reasons, many people prefer despensas to supermarkets.

With this in mind, Gonzalina decided to open a despensa in her house. She had previous experience in selling and dealing with customers because she had worked in a retail store. Using that previous experience, Gonzalina quickly attracted a large number of loyal customers.

Gonzalina is married to Claudio Ojeda, 47, and the couple has two boys. Thanks to Gonzalina’s entrepreneurial motivation, the family has its own house and her sons are going to college.

The money provided by the loan would be used to purchase more products to be sold in the despensa, including sugar, rice, milk, cheese, bread, and pasta.

loans.use: To buy products for a general store, including sugar, rice, milk, cheese, bread, and pasta

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en: Gulchehra is running a catering business where she is providing meals of the national cuisine. She is renting the catering room in a caravan which is located in the central local market. This allows Gulchehra to have many clients; The majority of which are those making purchases in the market. Every day, Gulchehra purchases the latest foods and cooks delicious dishes. Her daughter and sister help her with her business. The business has been generating a stable income during the last 7 years. The husband of Gulchehra is unemployed and her business is their only source of income. Now Gulchehra is planning to purchase kitchenware. For this purpose, she requests $600 dollars for the term of 12 months. Gulchehra had been provided with several loans by IMON and had proven herself as a reliable client. Today she thanks all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: Purchasing of kitchenware

loans.name: Zarafo

texts.en: Zarafo T.  is 28 years old and she runs a beauty salon. At the salon she provides  various services such as hair styling, haircutting, manicure, and the services of a cosmetologist. At the same time, the salon provides wedding dresses and accessories for decorating the wedding car for hire. Zarafo's salon is quite successful and generates a stable income for the family. Now Zarafo is planning to purchase new wedding dresses and accessories for decorating the wedding car to rent out. With this purpose in mind,  she is requesting a loan in the amount of 3400 Somoni (US$ 1000) for the term of 12 months. Zarafo thanks all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: Purchasing wedding dresses and accessories for decorating the wedding car

loans.name: Maria Gabriela

texts.es:
Maria Gabriela is a merchant of new clothing, a job that has come about from the lack of employment. She had a job but she was fired when she got pregnant, but even today she continues with her business./p>

She lives in her own house and she has two children who are still minors. One is attending primary school at Asuncion Primary School and the other is still a newborn. Her husband works in the fast food and delivery sector, these being the primary income of the family.

The sales she carries on are in cash and by credit (collecting weekly and bi-weekly payments) for clients in the area. She makes her purchases in Managua and Chinandega.

Her dream is to set up a clothing store in her house and to settle in to her house because they had little time. She wants to remodel because the new house is not finished lacking bedrooms, bathrooms and other divisions.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Gabriela, es comerciante de ropa nueva, actividad que surge como una alternativa al desempleo ya que estuvo trabajando pero al salir embarazada fue despedida, y actualmente trabaja con dicho negocio. Vive en casa propia es casada tiede dos hijos menores de edad, una estudia primaria en el colegio la asunción y el otro es recien nacido, su esposo trabaja en servicios de comida rapida con entega a domicilio, siendo los ingresos del nuceo familiar. Sus ventas las realiza de contado y credito que recupera en abonos semanales y quincenales, a clientes del sector, sus compras las realiza en managua y chinandega. Sus sueños son instalar una tienda de ropa en su casa de habitación y acondicionar su casa ya que es casa nueva teniendo poco tiempo de haberse traslado a este domicilio y no tiene las condiciones necesarias como cuarto, baños, en especial divisiones internas del inmueble.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Lucía

texts.es:
Mrs. Lucia M. M. has been a client of Emprender since 2002 and she has worked in this area for 18 years. Her husband is a bricklayer and he helps her pay her loan payments, and they have two children at home. In addition to selling food, she sells traditional products that she buys on the Peruvian border and then resells in the city of La Paz. To date she has made her payments responsibly and on time.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

La sra, Lucia M. M. es cliente de Emprender desde el año 2002 y trabaja en ese rubro desde hace unos 18 años. Su esposo es albañil, quien le colabora en el pago del crédito, tiene dos hijos aún dependientes. Además de la venta de comida, se dedica a repartir productos tradicionales, que compra en la frontera con el Perú y comercializa en la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz. A la fecha paga sus cuotas con responsabilidad y puntualmente.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Akpédjé Atifosé Kossiwa

texts.fr:
Née le 26 juin 1977 à Lomé, Madame S. Akpédjé Atifosé Kossiwa est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Elle a pour activité la vente de bijoux et de tissus Bazin dans les marchés des quartiers de Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 2001 et fait ses achats au bénin pour les bijoux et au mali pour les tissus bazin.
Elle a une fois bénéficié du crédit auprès de WAGES et a bien remboursé. 
Ces derniers temps, elle reçoit plusieurs commandes de ses clients et n’arrive pas à les satisfaire.
Elle sollicite ce second crédit pour acheter 50 colliers complets et 20 tissus de Bazin d’origine malienne.
texts.en:
Born on June 26, 1977 in Lomé, Mrs. Akpédjé Atifosé Kossiwa S. is married and the mother of two children. Her business is selling costume jewelry and "Bazin" (a cloth that is very popular in West Africa) in various markets around Lomé. She began this business in 2001 and buys her costume jewelry in Benin and the "Bazin" in Mali.

She has already had one loan from WAGES that she correctly reimbursed. Recently, she has been getting a number of orders from her customers and is not able to fill them. She is requesting this second loan to buy 50 necklace/earring sets and 20 lengths of "Bazin" from Mali.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of costume jewelry and "bazin" cloth for re-sale

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros S. N., 26, works selling women's clothes at a busy market and typically makes around $2.50 profit. She currently lives with her four-year-old child and her father in Bateay district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her husband has not lived with her since he became employed by a garment factory in Phnom Penh City, but he still comes to visit her two or three times per month. Ros S. N. has applied for a loan to buy clothes wholesale from a market in order to expand her inventory because her client base is growing and they have demanded fashionable clothes.

loans.use: To by clothes wholesale and resell them to meet growing customer demand

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr: Penda S., 51 ans, mariée, 08 enfants  en charge dont  07 scolarisés. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Baghagha depuis 6 ans. Son activité consiste à acheter des poissons séchés à Baghagha pour revendre à Dakar. Elle veut un prêt pour renforcer son commerce. Les revenus  tirés de son commerce vont lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Penda S. is 51 years old, married, and has 8 children in her care, of whom 7 are in school. She has been a member of the village loan group of Baghagha for 6 years. Her business consists of buying dried fish in Baghagha to re-sell in Dakar. She is asking for a loan to strengthen her business. The income drawn from her business will allow her to improve her family's living conditions. The loan she is asking for will be reimbursed at the end of six months in a single payment.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and re-sell dried fish

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios, 47 years old, is married to Maximo Sr., a driver. They are blessed with five children: Jovilyn, Maximo Jr., Samuel, Ruben, and Herson. Two of their children already have their own families, but still continue to live with them. Their unmarried children stopped studying due to financial problems. They live in the urban area of Osmenia Ilagan, Isabela. Remedios simply relates that they help each other in order to survive life’s difficulties. 

Remedios opened a canteen in the village where she displays and sells snack and viands. She earns an average weekly net income of PHP2,000 from her canteen. She hopes to borrow P10,000, which she will use to expand her business. 

Remedios said that sacrifice is the only key to the growth of her business. She is thankful that there are people and institutions who are willing to lend money to poor people like her, who want to uplift themselves. She has a good repayment record and is maintaining this, so that she will always be trusted by the lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Zulma Diana

texts.es:
La señora Zulma Diana V. D. Z. tiene 31 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras y vive en la calle Lambayeque 243 del Puerto Marítimo D. Salaverry D. la provincia D. Trujillo del departamento D. La Libertad Perú.
Estudió educación secundaria completa y se casó a los 18 años por lo que no pudo continuar estudios superiores. Tiene 3 hijos que dependen D. ella.
Su negocio lo realiza en su casa, venD. productos D. belleza y en ocasiones electrodomésticos.
El primer crédito D. 300 soles que fue cancelado en 4 cuotas, lo invirtió en la compra D. promoción D. productos (productos en oferta).
Con este crédito D. 1200 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas lo invertirá en comprar colchas D. tela polar.
Zulma desea tener una gran tienda donD. pueda abastecer a todo el puerto.
texts.en:
Zulma Diana V. D. Z. is 31 years old, and she belongs to the Banco Comunal Las Emprendadoras. She lives at Calle Lambayeque 243 of the Puerto Marítimo D. Salaverry in the Trujillo province, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.

She completed high school and got married at age 18, which prevented her from pursuing further education. She has three children who depend on her. She operates her business from her home, selling beauty products and occasionally some household appliances.

Her first loan of 300 soles, which she paid off in four installments, was used to purchase promotion for her products. With this loan of 1200 soles, which will be paid back in six installments, she will purchase bedspreads maD. from polar fleece for her to sell. Zulma wishes to someday own a big store from which she could supply the entire port.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bedspreads made from polar fleece

loans.name: Abdumalik

texts.en:
Abdumalik is 30 years old. He is married with 4 kids who are all going to kindergarten. Abdumalik has a small restaurant where he sells breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Prior to opening his own business, he worked at a restaurant where he learned the ins and outs of the trade. When he first started his business, he only opened to sell breakfast because he worked at night. Once his place became more popular, he was able to dedicate his whole time to the business.

Abdumalik wants the loan so he may invest in tables, chairs, and utensils, and in that way he proposes to expand his business. He is asking for 800 USD with a term of 6 months. With this money, Abdumalik will be able to expand his business, to earn more profit and in turn help his children move forward to attend school and university and in future become well-educated persons. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Contribute to the growth of Abdumalik’s business and they will be grateful!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing tables, chairs, and utensils to expand his cafe

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Mme Abra A. est née en 1980 à Bolou dans la préfecture du Zio. C’est une femme mariée avec trois (03) enfants à charge. Elle n’a pas eu la chance de poursuivre ses études et s’est lancée très tôt dans de petits commerces notamment la vente de produits de premières nécessités. Malgré l’expérience qu’elle a acquise dans ce domaine, elle manque cruellement de fonds pour développer son activité. Elle sollicite donc un crédit pour doper son commerce en s’approvisionnant suffisamment en marchandises. Cela lui permettra d’augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Ms. Abra A. was born in 1980 in Bolou in Zio prefecture. She is a married woman with three children in her care. Not having had the chance to pursue schooling, she got started early on with small-scale commerce, notably the sale of essential goods. Despite the experience she has acquired in this field, she is terribly short of funds for developing her business. She’s therefore requesting a loan to boost her commerce by supplying herself with sufficient merchandise. This will enable her to increase her income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell essential goods

loans.name: Mae

texts.en:
Mae D. is a "sari-sari" store owner. She is 55 years old and has one child.  She started her business using her small savings of Php 2,000.  Through the years, she was able to manage and sustain her business, which she uses to clothe and feed her family. She wanted all her children to graduate from college, so when they are older they could find better jobs to support their future families.

Mae is requesting a loan of 18,000PHP from CEVI.  She will use the loan to buy additional stock for her store. The loan will help Mae attract more customers and earn bigger income for her children.

CEVI gives its client credit, trainings and insurance coverage. Through CEVI micro financing efforts, more and more are able to start and make their business grow.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Mariaelena

texts.en:
Mariaelena is a member of the Santo Domingo Village Bank. She is 39 years old and is married with two children who are 13 and 9 years old. Mariaelena and her husband own a van, which they use as a school bus for local children. Her husband usually drives the van, but if he is busy or has to travel Mariaelena fills in or hires a replacement driver. She first bought a van with the help of a loan from Arariwa several years ago. Since then, she has replaced that van (which she laughingly describes as “fifth-hand”) with a newer one.

Mariaelena and her husband also have a farm in Mollepata, about two hours outside of the city of Cusco, where they seasonally harvest apples, pears, and beans.

Mariaelena is requesting a loan of 3,000 soles to redo the upholstery in her van and to buy different varieties of beans to plant. She has been working with Asociación Arariwa for the past three years, and has been a very responsible, reliable client. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan on time and in full. 
 
Mariaelena’s dream for the future is to finish construction on the home she is currently having built for her family. She would like to take out an individual loan from Asociacion Arariwa in order to do so.

loans.use: Re-upholster van, buy bean seeds to plant

loans.name: Mrs. Rorn Nhin Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of fifteen members, is located in Trapeang L. village in Takeo province. The members plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes.

Mrs. Rorn N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Naem Roun, is a construction worker. Although they try to work hard they still earn too little income to provide a better house for their family. Thus, Mrs. Rorn N. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy timbers to build the house. She is 40 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK, Kiva's partner, has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy timbers for building a house.

loans.name: Changamukeni Group

texts.en:
Pascal M. is thirty years old and single with two children, ages six and two.  He started a general store six years ago and works from 6am to 10pm every day. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $59.

This will be Pascal’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania (one of Kiva's field partners).  He used the previous loans to start a retail shop and to increase inventory in both stores, and he has paid back his loans successfully.  He wants to use the new loan to increase the inventory of both businesses.

Pascal will share this loan with his group "Changamkeni". The group has fifteen members. These members  hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Pascal is first on the left in the back row, wearing a white t-shirt.

loans.use: To increase the inventory in both shops.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma M. is from the village of Clarin, Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Wilma is separated from her spouse and has one adult child. To make a living, Wilma owns and operates a "sari-sari" or general retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Wilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in her "sari-sari" or retail store. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Wilma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Azucena

texts.es: Azucena tiene 47 años, es madre de un hijo de 20 años por quien se esfuerza para brindarle lo necesario para su educación, a pesar de no tener una casa propia tiene el sueño de adquirir una pronto y dejar de pagar alquileres. Desde que su pareja la abandonó tuvo la valentía de salir adelante sola trabajando como costurera, oficio que viene realizando por más de 20 años. En sus inicios trabajó en su casa recibiendo algunos pedidos de sus vecinos para arreglar sus prendas; posteriormente, la municipalidad abrió un mercado en el distrito donde vivía y supo aprovechar la oportunidad para adquirir un puesto, donde viene trabajando desde hace 10 años. Azucena atiende a sus clientes desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche, ahora que es más conocida y tiene gran cantidad de clientes está pensando ampliar su puesto aprovechando la disponibilidad de los que tiene al costado y están en venta. Este es su 9no crédito con Microfinanzas PRISMA, la responsabilidad y el empeño son cualidades que comparte con sus compañeras de banco comunal, con quienes ha aprendido a desenvolverse en los ámbitos sociales y comerciales. Los 2000 soles que solicita le permitirán adquirir telas y herramientas para desarrollar mejor los acabados de sus confecciones.
texts.en:
Azucena (Lily) is a 47 years old mother with a 20 year old son for whom she works hard to offer him what is necessary for his education, despite not having her own house she has the dream of acquiring one soon and to let go of paying rent. Ever since her partner left her, she had the bravery to move forward alone working as a seamstress, a trade she has made for more than 20 years. In the beginning, she worked at home receiving some orders from her neighbors to fix their garments; later, the municipality opened a market in the district where she lived and she knew to take advantage of the opportunity to acquire a place, where she has been working for 10 years. Azucena (Lily) takes care of her clients from 8 in the morning to 10 at night. Now that she is more well-known and has a great amount of clients, she is thinking of extending her place, taking advantage of the availability of what is for sale to her side. This is her 9th loan with Microfinanzas PRISM, responsibility and persistence are qualities that she shares with her companions of the communal bank, with those who have learned to develop themselves in the social and commercial scopes. The 2000 soles that she asks for will allow her to acquire fabrics and tools to better develop her tailoring.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Lualua

texts.en: Lualua M., 43, is married and has 10 children. She has 2 years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village people two days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 160 Tala (~$100 USD).  SPBD loans are Lualua’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase bush knives, rake, wheelbarrow, planting instruments, and taro roots

loans.name: Tomasa Josefa

texts.es: Doña tomasa josefa es una persona que vive a ocho kilometros del pueblo, la cual con todos los esfuerzos ha podido iniciar su negocio en compra y venta de ropa tipica, y tambien ella elabora ropa tipica para su ampiacion de capital y a base de esto ha mejorado sus condiciones de vida, y tiene la vision de seguir creciendo en su negocio, la cual se vio en la nesesidad de acudir a la asociacion asdir para pedir un apoyo de un prestamo para mantener la sostenibilidad de su negocio y mejorar el servicio a los clientes.
texts.en:
Doña Tomasa Josefa lives 8 kilometers outside of town. With great effort, she started a business buying and selling traditional clothing. She also makes traditional clothes as a way of increasing her inventory. In order for her to improve her living conditions, she envisions growing her business.

For this reason, she finds it necessary to approach Asociación ASDIR for assistance. She will use her loan to sustain her business and improve customer service.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her operating capital

loans.name: Salam Plus Kis Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Salama Plus est la deuxième banque communautaire de Kisangani d’avoir bénéficié des prêts de Kiva. Il est constitué de 26 micro-entrepreneurs dont N’sila B. est membre. Cette ville de Kisangani située au nord de la ligne de l’Equateur, est dans la province Orientale de la République Démocratique du Congo et est frontalière au nord-est avec le Soudan et l’Ouganda. Elle a été victime des guerres entre deux armées étrangères en 2000 an.
N’sila vend de l’huile de palme, du riz, du maїs au marché I.A.T dans la ville de Kisangani. Il a depuis 2000 an gagné assez d’expériences dans le petit commerce. La vente du carburant fut sa première activité avec un capital initial de $20. Au fil des ans, N’sila a changé d’activité et est parvenu à se constituer une clientèle fidèle pour l’avancement de son affaire. Ses ambitions sont, premièrement, effectuer des voyages d’affaires à l’avenir en vue de fournir à la population de la ville des produits sollicités. Deuxièmement, construire une maison pour sa famille. Il a obtenu 5 fois les crédits de l’IMF HOPE RDC et a remboursé correctement. Actuellement, son affaire lui génère un bénéfice de $40 par semaine. Vu la demande qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le prêt qu’il recevra prochainement lui permettra de renforcer le stock des marchandises en achetant des produits alimentaires du même genre. N’sila est âgé de 36 ans, marié et père de 2 filles et 2 garçons âgés entre 8 et 16 ans dont trois d’entre eux sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
The group Salama Plus is the second community bank of Kisangani to have benefited from Kiva loans. The group is composed of 26 micro-entrepreneurs, including a member named N’sila B.. This city of Kisangani, located north of the equator, is in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and it’s on the border with Sudan and Uganda to the northeast. The city was the victim of wars between two foreign armies in 2000. N’sila sells palm oil, rice, and corn at the I.A.T market in the city of Kisangani. Since 2000, he has gained a fair amount of small business experience. Selling fuel was his first business with $20 in initial capital. Over the years, he changed businesses and has managed to establish a loyal customer base for advancing his business. His ambitions are, first of all, to take business trips in the future with the aim of supplying the people of the city with sought-after goods. Secondly, it’s to build a house for his family. He obtained five loans from the micro-finance institution HOPE RDC, and he repaid them appropriately. Right now, his business generates a profit of $40 a week. Given the ever-increasing demand, the loan he’ll receive next will allow him to bolster his inventory of merchandise by purchasing food items of the same type. N’sila is 36 years old, married, and the father of two girls and two boys, ages 8 to 16. Three of them are in school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his inventory by buying goods to sell for increasing his revenues

loans.name: Maria Cruz

texts.es: La señora Maria Cruz, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de Guadalupe II”, vive en el Jr. Belén Nº 650, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es conviviente, tiene 45 años tiene 3 hijos, 01 varón y 02 mujeres,  todos aun en etapa escolarSu espíritu emprendedor y la necesidad de ayudar en el ingreso económico del hogar le motivo a iniciarse en el negocio y no vio la mejor manera de hacerlo con el primer préstamo que le otorgaron de S/. 300.00,  con esto ella compró lo que mas le pedían los vecinos quienes fueron sus primeros clientes, hoy continua con la misma actividad, ella vende de manera ambulatoria en la ciudad y los fines de semana sale a los pueblos mas cercanos  para incrementar sus ventas. Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00, comprará polos, para damas caballeros y niños, blusas, pantalones de hombre y mujer, pijamas, ropa de bebe, sabanas y colchas que son los que mas salida tienen entre su clientela; le gusta contar con stock de mercadería para poder satisfacer las exigencias de  sus clientes.Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo que le demanda bastante tiempo ,  cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida como son el de tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Cruz belongs to the community bank “Virgen de Guadalupe II” (Virgin of Guadalupe II). She lives in Jr. Belén Nº 650, Bagua Grande District, Utcubamba Province, Department of Amazonas. She is 45 years old and lives with three children, one boy and two girls, all of whom are still in grade school. Her enterprising spirit and the necessity of helping with household income motivated her to go into business, though she didn’t see the best way of doing so.

With the first loan granted to her of 300 soles she purchased what the neighbors who were her first customers asked for the most. Today, she continues with the same activity. She sells in an itinerant manner in the city, and on weekends she goes to nearby towns in order to increase her sales.

With this loan of 1000 soles she will buy polo shirts for women, men and children; blouses; men’s and women’s pants; pajamas; baby clothes; sheets and comforters that are most in demand among her customers. She likes to have an inventory of merchandise in order to be able to satisfy the requirements of her customers. She feels very satisfied with her work. Though it demands a lot of time, she believes that it is worth the sacrifice in order to achieve her dreams and goals that she has planned for her life, such as having her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy clothes in order to increase her inventory

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
Mrs. Nat T., age 54, and her husband, Mr. Ke T., age 60, live in a small village along National Road Number Five, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1972 and have six children: one son and five daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, three daughters work in a garment factory and other two children attend school. 
 
Nat has been selling Khmer noodles for two years. Mr. Ke T. has been growing rice since 1979, and he assists his wife in the business when he is free. For the future, the couple hopes to support their children’s further education and have a job. 

Nat doesn’t have her own transportation so she is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Athou

texts.en: Athou K. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables  and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil to sell.  Athou is 30 years old and is Married with a husband that is a builder. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for the family BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Cusisiña Group

texts.es:
“Cusisiña” escrito en aymará significa “nos alegraremos”, así se denomina un grupo de 14 mujeres que se agruparon recientemente para acceder al préstamo.
En una de sus reuniones elaboran su reglamente interno, además eligen a su mesa directiva como L. Presidenta, Tesorera, Secretaria de Actas, Responsable Popular de Capacitación y  Responsable Popular de Salud. Tanto ellas como L. base tienen sus propios negocios como L. costura de polleras (faldas), venta de queso, tejido de manoplas, venta de material de construcción y venta de quinua. Todas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería, insumos o materia prima y seguir mejorando sus negocios, con L. esperanza de darles a sus familias mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
“Cusisiña” written in the Aymará language means "we will be happy". That is the name of a group of 14 women who recently joined together to gain access to a loan. In one of their meetings they drew up their bylaws and elected the board of directors including the President, the Treasurer, the Recording Secretary, the Head of People's Training, and the Head of People's Health. Those directors as well as the base members have their own businesses such as sewing skirts, selling cheese, knitting mittens, selling construction materials, and selling quinua (a nutritious cereal/grain). They all need the loan to buy merchandise, supplies, or raw materials and to continue improving their businesses with the hope of providing their families with improved living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise, supplies, and raw materials

loans.name: Sinignèsigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèsigui de l’association Badenya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce d’articles divers (tels le poisson, le tissu, le savon, les céréales etc.) à Tominian il y’a environ 15 ans. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Sinignèsigui de l’association Badenya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur premier prêt.    
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat d’un important stock de produits divers auprès de grossistes. Ces activités sont très rentables pour ces femmes qui vendent en détail surtout. 
Les membres du groupe Sinignèsigui comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000 FCFA à 17.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Sinignèsigui of the association Badenya is composed of married women of the city of Tominian, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women live in traditional families and average 31 years of age and 6 children each.  For about fifteen year in Tominian, the women of the group have had small businesses involving a variety of goods (such as fish, cloth, soap, grains, etc.) To make their work profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their first loan.  The current loan will be used to buy a major stock of various goods from wholesale merchants.  These businesses are very worthwhile for these women who sell especially at the retail level.  The group members each plan on realizing an average monthly profit of 10,000 to 17,000 francs CFA that will be used for paying the loan interest and for common family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods (fish, fabrics, soaps, beans, etc.)

loans.name: Gisma

texts.en: Gisma J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Gisma is 30 years old and is married to a builder. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This loan is being requested by a group of 15 people who live in Rumchek village in Takeo province.  Mrs. Sam H., a silk weaver,  was selected as village bank president by the members of the group.  This business is going well, so she would like to buy more silk to weave for her customers.  She plans to use her portion of the loan to buy more silk. 

Her husband, Mr. Tun Saor, is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field where he cultivates rice for a living. Mrs. Sam H. is 52 years old and the mother of two children.  One of her children is a driver and makes a small salary that helps support the family.  The youngest child attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave for her customers.

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en:
Khatira Q. is 33 years old and comes from a large and humble family. She is married and has four children. As she had only high school education and had never worked, she decided to start her business to financially help her husband, so Khatira dedicates herself to raising and selling cows. The income she generates provides a better quality of life for her family.

She is asking for a loan of 1600 AZN in order to buy calves to sell later when they are fully grown. With this investment, Khatira will be able to substantially increase her earnings and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase four calves

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Bárbara 2” desde hace 9 años atrás, del distrito de Chucuito, provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 45 años de edad, es casada y tiene 03 hijos. Ella estudió primaria incompleta.  Ella tiene un restaurante.

Juana nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, lo que le sirvió para aumentar su capital.

Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar arroz, papa, carne.

Su sueño para el futuro es trabajar y mejorar cada día... así progresar. 

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la puntualidad de las socias y las promotoras para cada reunión.
texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the community bank "Santa Bárbara 2" for 9 years in the district of Chucuito, from the province and region of Puno. She is 45 years old, married, and three children. She has an incomplete primary school education. She runs a restaurant. Juana's first loan request to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos was for S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, which she used to increase her business capital. She requests a loan of S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, with which she will be able to buy rice, potatoes, and meat. Her dream for the future is to work and improve each day ... and through these means, progress. What she likes most about her community bank is the punctuality of the members and the promoters for each meeting.

Translated from Spanish by Colleen Godfrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, potatoes, and meat

loans.name: Boikuzi

texts.en:
Since 2006, Boikuzi has been a livestock farmer. He breeds calves and cows. He is married and has two children whom he needs to support and give a proper education to. Boikuzi has improved his financial situation because he has been able to use the loans he has received from IMON International wisely to breed his animals. Nowadays, his biggest dream is to expand his business and to offer animal derivates (as dairy products) in the areas surrounding his community. Therefore, his biggest need is to get a loan in order to buy more cows.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Erika Roxana

texts.es:
Erika tiene 39 años de edad, es soltera, vive en casa de sus padres y hermanas. 
Ella es propietaria de una bodega ubicada en una zona rural de la ciudad de Ica, inicio el 
negocio aproximadamente hace 5 años, inicio con un capital pequeño producto de ahorros 
obtenidos, en la actualidad su capital se ha ido incrementando  con mucho esfuerzo fruto de su trabajo. Ella actualmente atiende el negocio de manera calida y amable ya que la gran mayoría 
de sus clientes son personas que laboran en los fundos ubicados en los alrededores de su bodega. 
Erika sueña con tener su casa propia, pero por el momento se hace cargo de sus padres 
los cuales ya son de edad avanzada. Ella quisiera brindarles los cuidados y atenciones 
debidos, pero los ingresos que obtiene, no le permite asumir estos gastos, por este 
motivo es que solicita el crédito para incrementar su mercadería y asi poder tener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Erika is 39 years old, single, and lives with her parents and sisters. She runs a small store in a rural area of the city of Ica; she started the business 5 years ago with a small amount of capital from her savings. Her capital has increased due to the fruits of her hard work. She attends to her customers with a great degree of service and friendliness; the majority of her customers work on the large farms close to her store. Erika dreams of owning her own home, but now she takes care of her parents who are elderly. She would like to take better care of them but her income is insufficient to provide everything she would like for them. This loan will be used to increase her inventory and help her improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Dolores Inés

texts.es:
La señora Dolores P. tiene 45 años, vive en la comunidad Punta Corral con su esposo albañil de oficio y gracias a su esfuerzo  y dedicación demostró que se  puede salir adelante sin dejar su país,  muestra de ello es haber construido su casa propia, tienen cuatro hijos que oscilan entre los 24 y 18 años de edad de ellos los tres primeros ya trabajan pero sólo para sus gastos personales. Dolores es socia del Banco Comunal  Mujer y Fortaleza  hace varios ciclos pero se retiro y ahora regresa con más ganas de seguir trabajando junto a su banco comunal  que se formó en la parroquia Turi al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, sector conocido como el balcón de la ciudad  y es un sitio  muy turístico por la belleza natural del campo, la gastronomía y la amabilidad de su gente donde la mayor parte de su población  se dedica a la agricultura y también a otras  actividades que les permiten salir adelante junto a sus familias.

Dolores es costurera y confecciona polleras siendo esta una de las vestimentas tradicionales de la mujer de ésta región y  fue una vecina la que le enseño este arte en el cual  lleva cuatro años trabajando,  además  se dedica al cuidado y cría de una vaca lechera y su producción de leche es solo para el consumo familiar,  con el credito solicito va a pagar la primera cuota para la compra de una máquina de coser para ir incrementando y mejorando  poco a poco  su negocio, su gran sueño es ponerse un taller propio con su hija de 18 años que también le gusta la costura.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dolores P. is 45 years old, lives in the Punta Corral neighborhood with her husband. He is a builder by trade and thanks to his hard work and dedication they have proven that they can get ahead without leaving their country. This is shown in the fact that they built their own home and have four children between the ages of 24 and 18, the oldest three already working to cover their own expenses. Dolores is a member of the community bank, Mujer y Fortaleza (Women and Strength). As of various loan cycles ago she had retired from the group and is now returning with more desire than ever to continue working with the community bank, which was formed in the Turi parish at the southeastern side of the city of Cuenca. This section is known as the balcony of the city and is a very popular tourist area due to its natural beauty, food and the friendliness of its people. The majority of the population works in agriculture, and other activities that allow them to get their families ahead. Dolores is a seamstress and makes skirts, that are the traditional mode of dress for women of this region. A neighbor taught her this trade and she has been doing it for four years. She also takes care and raises a milk cow, the milk yield is only for the use of the family. With the proceeds of the requested loan she will pay the first installment toward the purchase of a sewing machine and little by little improve her business. Her biggest dream is to open her own shop with her 18 year old daughter, who also likes to sew.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay the first installment for the purchase of a sewing machine.

loans.name: Norma Evangelina

texts.es:
El banco comunal Barrio Sucre se encuentra en la parroquia de Cumbe al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, sugente se dedica principalmente a la elaboración de artesanías de tejido, bordado e hilado de lana de oveja para la confección de sus prendas de vestir,  también se dedica a la agricultura y muchos de ellos han migrado a las grandes ciudades o al exterior en busca de un mejor futuro para sus familias.

La señora Norma G. vive a las afueras de la Ciudad de Cuenca en la parroquia Cumbe, tiene 49 años de edad esta casada y fruto de su unión ha concebido seis hijos que oscilan entre los 30 20 años de edad  algunos de ellos ya son casados, su casa es propia y aqui habita con dos de sus hijos aún solteros, el de 25 ya trabja y aporta con los gastos de la familia, su esposo se encuentra en el extranjero hace mucho tiempo en busca del sueño americano para brindarles  mejores oportunidades a su familia.

Norma tiene una pequeña tienda en la que  lleva cinco años laborando y ya que cuenta con su clientela fija, también cría  animales y sale los miércoles a vender sus gallinas y  cuyes en la parroquia donde habita, se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo trabajando junto a  la fundación gracias  Rosa Tenecela otra  socia de su banco comunal que la invito a formar parte del mismo, con el nuevo crédito solicitado comprará gallinas, cuyes, chanchos, afrechillo, maíz y algunos productos como arroz, azúcar, aceite, para abastecer su tienda.

Su gran sueño es construir un galpón para incrementar su criadero de pollos.
texts.en:
The Barrio Sucre ("Sucre Neighborhood") communal bank is located in the parish of Cumbe, southeast of the city of Cuenca. The people of the area mainly work creating woven and embroidered handicrafts or spinning sheep's wool to make clothing. They also work in agriculture, and many of them have migrated to the larger cities or abroad in search of a better future for their families. Norma G. lives in the outskirts of the city of Cuenca, in Cumbe parish. She is 49 years old and married. Out of this marriage have come six children, who now range from 20 to 30 years old. Some of them are already married. Norma owns her house and lives in it with two of her children who are still single. The 25-year-old already works and helps with the household expenses. Norma's husband has been abroad for a long time, in search of the American dream, in order to provide his family with better opportunities. Norma has a small store where she has worked for five years. Since she has a steady customer base, she is also able to raise animals, and she goes out on Wednesdays to sell her chickens and guinea pigs in the parish where she lives. She is in her fourth loan cycle with the Foundation, thanks to Rosa Tenecela, another member of her communal bank, who invited her to join. With the new loan she is requesting, she will buy chickens, guinea pigs, pigs, feed pellets, corn, and some products to stock her store, such as rice, sugar and cooking oil. Her great dream is to construct a shed so she can expand her chicken farm.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying chickens, guinea pigs, pigs, feed pellets and corn; and rice, sugar, oil and noodles to stock her store

loans.name: Sammy

texts.en:
Sammy is a 60-year-old married man living near the town of Kitale, in western Kenya. He has twelve children, ranging in age from 15 to 30 years old, with three of them currently attending school.
Sammy has been running his mixed farm for over ten years now, and sells a wide variety of products at the market. His primary income comes from the sale of maize, beans, milk and eggs, while he also earns income from his ownership of a motorbike. He says that lately the main challenges to his business are the fluctuation in market prices and changes in climatic conditions, which negatively affect production.
Sammy is a new client of Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo. He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to start a poultry farming operation. He says that the extra income from this loan will ensure that his family's needs are well catered for. He has plans for expansion in the next five to ten years, and his main goal is to increase the number of dairy animals and poultry stock he owns, thus generating more income.

loans.use: To start a poultry farming operation

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 33 years old, married to Veronica Nyambura, and they have two school-going children.  He has operated his taxi in Naivasha town for the last three years, ferrying people and goods from one place to another.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan.  His first loan of 30,000 KES was used to service his taxi and he paid the loan well and on time.  He plans to use the money he gets from this current loan to buy a new engine for his taxi.

He hopes to grow in the business industry and buy his own minibus.

loans.use: Buy a new engine for his taxi

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa B. sells a variety of soaps in Akotokyire moving from one customer to the next. Yaa has been through senior high school. She is married and has four children. She helps her husband take care of their home. Her loan will be used to buy more and different varieties of soap to resell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more soaps

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a mother of 1 and she is 32 years of age. She lives in Lagos and she sells ice block to customers. Her husband is a civil servant and they reside in Lagos. She and her husband work hard in order to improve their living standard.  She has been in her business for 3 years and she loves the business very well. 

She hopes for business expansion and she is requesting for the loan of NGN150, 000 to purchase one freezer and generating set to more ice block to sell. This will enable her make more ice block and avoid the problem of power failure. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase one freezer and generating set to make more ice block to sell.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Lun T., 52, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a tailor and earns an income of about $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  T. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a mechanical plow. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a mechanical plow

loans.name: Patient Group

texts.en:
Abdul T. (pictured on the right) is the leader of this group. He was born in Matotoka village which is about eight miles away from Magburaka town. Abdul is 30-year-old. He is single and has no children. Abdul sells cassette tapes, tape recorders, radios, torch-light/push lights, batteries, etc. He has been running this business for many years. With his share of the loan (1,200,000 leones), he will expand his business by buying the above mentioned items.

In the picture are members of the Patient Group and loan officer, Mohmaed L. Tarawalie, handing over the loan. They are small scale businessmen in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, seeking a loan of 1,200,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy cassette tapes, tape recorders, radios, torch-light/push lights, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Mario Alberto

texts.es:
La persona que aparece en la foto es la esposa del señor.
Mario Alberto P. G. es un hombre trabajador dispuesto a  ofrecer a su familia una mejora calidad de vida. Desde hace varios años el obtuvo una casa de interés social a la cual le ha ido haciendo mejoras poco a poco; este sacrificio que el hace es para darles una mejor comodidad a sus 2 hijos junto con su esposa. El proyecto que el tiene es levantar un barda en la parte de enfrente para dar seguridad a su familia.
Mario trabaja en una maquiladora en el día y de noche trabaja en taxi para así obtener más ingresos y así suplir los gastos es por ello que no aparece en la imagen.
texts.en:
The person that appears in the photo is the wife of the man.

Mario Alberto P. G. is a hardworking man set to offer his family a better quality of life. For some years he got a house which he has been fixing little by little, the sacrifices that he does are to provide his 2 children and wife a more convenient living environment. The project that he has is to make a fence for the front of his home to provide security to his family.

Mario works in a maquiladora (factory/assembly plant) in the day and during the night he works in a taxi to have more income and to meet the household expenses, that is why he is not in the picture.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a fence.

loans.name: Mairamkul's Group

texts.en: Infrastructure within a city plays a crucial role in the wellbeing of its residents. A city with many factories, enterprises and companies has a lot to offer for its residents regarding jobs and career opportunities. Tash Komur city used to be a prospering coal mining city with a predominantly Russian population. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the mining process stopped and the whole process of development of the city’s infrastructure deteriorated. Now, this city is one of those cities that are regarded as dead cities, due to its high level of migration and unemployment. Our heroes are today’s residents of this city and Mairamkul T. is the leader of this group. She is a widow and has raised her children, facing all the difficulties herself. Now she is forty-two and, to provide for her family, she is occupied with cattle breeding. About fifteen years ago, she bought a cow and three goats and started raising cattle. Apart from that, she is also engaged in farming, growing certain kinds of vegetables. Mairamkul is the mother of four children. Her eldest son is a tractor driver and the rest of her children are daughters who help her look after the cattle and the garden. Mairamkul has applied for this loan as she wants to buy one more cow so as to have more milk for sale. She plans to send her eldest daughter to Jalalabad city to a medical school. Mairamkul’s partners: Aigerim T., 19, is married and has a daughter. She trades in watermelons and vegetables, as her mother-in-law offered to look after her child. Sometimes she and her husband sell vegetables by driving around the city in their car. Aigerim needs a loan to repair their kitchen. Meriza S., 19, is single and lives with her grandmother. To provide for herself and her grandmother, she grows vegetables, breeds cattle, and works as a waitress in a café. She needs this loan to buy two calves. Kubataaly K., 65, is retired. He grows corn, tomatoes and onions and, besides this, he keeps cattle. By having two occupations, he has been able to build a two-story house. He needs a loan to build a winter kitchen. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase one more cow

loans.name: Julia Leonor

texts.es:
La Señora Julia Leonor R. es socia del banco comunal Rosas Rojas, vive en la comunidad de La Estancia que  pertenece al cantón Paute,  se caracteriza por ser la mayor productora de flores, su gente en su mayor parte viven del la agricultura y ganadería.

Nuestra socia se dedica al cuidado de una hacienda de la localidad hace 22 años,  su trabajo en ella es de sembrar plantas para jardines y hortalizas, en la hacienda le permiten criar animales, tiene pollos, chanchos y cuyes los que vende cuando tiene  alguna necesidad económica.
 
La Señora Julia Leonor tiene 44 años, es madre soltera de  5 hijos de 25, 23, 20, 16 y 13 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos son casados,  viven con ella y comparten los gastos del hogar, su tercer hijo trabaja y también le ayuda económicamente, sus dos últimos hijos están estudiando en el colegio, gracias a su trabajo ha logrado construir su casa propia.

Se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo y los créditos le han servido para comprar más animales, su crédito lo va a invertir en la construcción de un galpón para cuyes.

Su meta es tener una mejor situación económica.
texts.en:
Julia Leonor R. is a member of the “Rosas Rojas” (Red Roses) Communal Bank. She lives in the La Estancia community, which belongs to the Paute canton. It is characterized as being the greatest flower producer. Most of its people live from farming and livestock. Our member has been taking care of a ranch in her area for 22 years. Her work is to plant the flower gardens and vegetables. On the ranch they allow her to raise animals. She has chickens, pigs, and guinea pigs. She sells them when she needs the money. Julia Leonor is 44 years old. She is a single mother, and she has five children. The children are 25, 23, 20, 16, and 13 years old. Her first two children are married. They live with her and share the household expenses. Her third child works and helps with expenses. Her last two children are in school. Thanks to her work she built her own house. She is in her fourth cycle. The loans have helped her buy more animals. She will use the loan to build housing for guinea pigs. Her goal is to have a better financial situation.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build guinea pig housing

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buying more stock of items like sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil and paraffin for resale

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun S., age 35, is married with three children, all of whom attend school and are dependent on her income. Hun S. is a domestic rice trader who buys rice in bulk at a reasonable cost.  After she mills the rice, she sells her finished rice to people for her income. Her husband is skilled in building ox-carts and uses his knowledge to earn a daily profit. Usually the family generates around $6.50 of profit a day to meet the needs of their family. There are a couple of neighbors selling cows at reasonable prices. Hun S. wants to buy a cow or two to raise for the purpose of selling for a profit. Because she doesn’t have cash, Hun S. decided to request a loan to buy it.

loans.use: To buy a cow or two.

loans.name: Ricardo Jose

texts.es: Ricardo José tiene 30 anos. Ricardo es un hombre. El se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos. El sabe que de manera ambulante puede obtener nuevos clientes y nuevos productos. Solicita el crédito para invertir en la compra de pantalones, camisas, faldas y cosméticos. Su sueño es darle educación a su hijo para que tenga éxito. Un desafío que ha enfrentado es que el precio de ciertos productos están muy caros. Le gusta el conversar con sus clientes y aconsejarlos a obtener lo mejor.
texts.en:
Ricardo José is a 30 year old man. He sells clothing and cosmetics. As a street vendor, he is able to obtain new customers and purchase new products. He is requesting the loan to purchase trousers, shirts, skirts, and cosmetics. His dream is to give his son an education so that he will be successful. One challenge which he has faced is the expensive prices of certain products. He enjoys talking with his customers and persuading them to buy the best quality products.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
Ana Maria A. is a widow who lives in Brgy. Campclark, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store.  Ana Maria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ana Maria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, improving the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for her general store so that she can continue to support her family and save for future home repairs. Ana Maria A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean M. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 56 years old and married. She has five children; the eldest is 32 and the youngest is 23 years old. To make a living, Jean plants and harvests rice for sale. With her income from her business, Jean also supports her grandchildren, especially in their education. 

Jean joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jean is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
La señora Graciela Rodríguez González  tiene 40 años de edad, vive en  Barrio San Pedro, tiene su vivienda, y  es madre soltera.
La señora Graciela  es muy trabajadora y con mucho sacrificio logró abrir su negocio, por los actualmente es comerciante posee una despensa bien surtida en su domicilio además elabora masas, pan casero, tortas para la venta y los vende en su negocio.
 Mediante esta actividad pueden solventar  sus gastos y cubrir cualquier imprevisto que se le presente se dedican a esta actividad hace mas de 10 años.  
Ella ha solicitado este crédito para la compra de productos de consumo familiar, bebidas, frutas y verduras.
texts.en:
Sra. Graciela Rodríguez González is 40 years old and lives in the neighborhood of San Pedro where she has a home. She is a single mother.

Sra. Graciela is a hard worker who has made great sacrifices to open her business. She is currently a merchant who has a well-stocked store in her home. In addition she produces cookies, homemade bread, and cakes to sell at her business. This business enables her to meet her expenses and prepare herself for any unexpected emergency. Graciela has been in business for more than ten years.

She is requesting this loan in order to buy household consumer products such as beverages, fruits, and vegetables.

loans.use: Purchase beverages, fruits, and vegetables

loans.name: Regina Maame Mansah

texts.en: Regina Maame Mansah P. is married to a driver and lives together with her two children. She has no educational background. Regina operates a food joint where she sells a variety of food at Elmina. This business has been in operation for about eight years.
